body: You should be able to get it working by adding the headers manually as needed for now via the `--headers` flag: https://rclone.org/docs/#header

Hmm... I'm trying it out and it does not seem to work. It seems to me that this is meant for the Request headers, when rclone is accessing a remote service?
Just to be clear, I'm looking for the server-side header `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *` when rclone is used via `rclone serve webdav`.

What I'm getting from rclone in that case is:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/462445/109427786-46b23f80-79f4-11eb-8510-861991a36c6c.png)

There's no CORS header.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/462445/109427887-ba544c80-79f4-11eb-8891-9bc45c4860bd.png)

The command I use is:

`rclone serve webdav xyz:notes/org --vfs-cache-mode full --header "Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *"`

Perhaps I'm doing something wrong here? Thanks for the assistance!
On a more careful look, yeah, this method won't work for the serve command since that uses its own http handler which doesn't have support for adding custom headers.

@darthShadow Can I pick up and work on this? I am trying to slowly step in one by one and understand the codebase. This seems like a place where I don't have to tackle a lot of complications and can figure out easily. Do you think I can work on this?

You can definitely give it a try.

You will need to look at the following files to get an idea of how rclone handles adding arbitrary headers:

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/fs/config/configflags/configflags.go -> For parsing
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/fs/fshttp/http.go -> For adding

And then add similar logic for https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/cmd/serve/httplib/httplib.go
@darthShadow thank you for the directions. I'll work on this over the weekend and quickly raise a PR on the same.

@darthShadow @MisterY - Sorry, I might not be able to work on this for next couple weeks. If somebody is interested to pick this up, let them. If this is still open after 2 weeks, I can definitely work on this. Sorry. :/

Are you going to continue with this project? There are different clients (KeeWeb, diffuse,...) that use CORS to function and they give error.

Thanks

issue.title: httplib: Allow CORS when serving

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

This fixes #5078 by adding basic support for [Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS) requests when serving http-based protocols. This means that webapps are able to send requests to this server even if they are on a different domain. The main usecase of this is to support webapps that don't manage their own storage but instead delegate to a WebDAV server, e.g. https://organice.200ok.ch/ from the linked issue.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

- #5078 

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
  - not sure how to test this so I've left this
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
> via the `--headers` flag

> this method won't work for the serve command since that uses its own http handler which doesn't have support for adding custom headers

Here I propose a new flag that takes care of headers in HTTP server responses, just like what `--headers` did for HTTP client requests.  I'm not sure what would be the proper name for the new flag though.  Maybe `--headers-serve`?

I have another issue with CORS when working with `rclone rcd`, and I found out the problem

The custom headers only apply **AFTER** the authorization is accepted, however when browser check CORS, they don't take `Authorization` header due to security concerns.

So, the best way is to use another option (not exposed to user) to set http header before the `Auth` middleware

I found this code

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/4f8dab8bcec40f34f02074549747437ac17b0bef/lib/http/server.go#L229

I think a new middleware (maybe `HeadersPreAuth`) before this line will help

And the old cli option `--rc-allow-origin` can be combined to a new option to control both `rclone rcd` and `rclone serve` to solve CORS and other http header issue

> I have another issue with CORS when working with `rclone rcd`, and I found out the problem
> 
> The custom headers only apply **AFTER** the authorization is accepted, however when browser check CORS, they don't take `Authorization` header due to security concerns.
> 
> So, the best way is to use another option (not exposed to user) to set http header before the `Auth` middleware
> 
> I found this code
> 
> https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/4f8dab8bcec40f34f02074549747437ac17b0bef/lib/http/server.go#L229
> 
> I think a new middleware (maybe `HeadersPreAuth`) before this line will help
> 
> And the old cli option `--rc-allow-origin` can be combined to a new option to control both `rclone rcd` and `rclone serve` to solve CORS and other http header issue

The thing to do would be to move the `allow-origin` option into `lib/http` then all the servers `rc` and other can make use of it.

Want to have a go at that @yuudi ?

> 
> The thing to do would be to move the `allow-origin` option into `lib/http` then all the servers `rc` and other can make use of it.
> 
> Want to have a go at that @yuudi ?

I'll give it a try this week

issue.title: http: Fix CORS issue of `rc` and `serve http/webdav`

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

fix CORS issue with `rclone serve http`, `rclone serve webdav`, `rclone rcd`

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

discussed at [#5078](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5078#issuecomment-1607847580)

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [x] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

~~**Help wanted for this PR:** I am not sure how to update the auto-generated documentation. This PR removed `--rc-allow-origin` option and added new `{prefix}-allow-origin` option ([source code](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/46e155ae0c4d7c667267bc2a4b49040c1eb44a65/lib/http/server.go#L126)). So the usage of `--rc-allow-origin` is not changed. I don't know if I need to update the documentation of this part. And this `{prefix}-allow-origin` also apply to `rclone serve http` and I don't know if I need to update this part.~~

edit:
I tried to run `make doc` and found everything is generated correctly.

issue.title: Enable CORS on Serve (WebDAV)

repository.name: Round-Sync
repository.description: An android cloud file manager, powered by rclone. Visit https://roundsync.com for more information!

issue.body:
#### Pre-Submission checklist - [x] There is no existing issue that already asks for this feature.
- [ ] The feature already exists in rclone (on your PC or in Termux) - [x] I am prepared to help make this feature #### What version of extRact are you using (About -> App version)? 2.1.3 #### What problem are you trying to solve? Serving a remote folder (say via WebDAV) does not allow connections from a PWA (in-browser web app) running on the same machine due to CORS. #### What should extRact be able to do differently to help with this problem? Allow all connections. Use the following header: ``` (Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *) ``` #### Related Rclone issue https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/5078
